eu.webtoolkit.jwt
Class WTreeTable

java.lang.Object
  eu.webtoolkit.jwt.WObject
      eu.webtoolkit.jwt.WWidget
          eu.webtoolkit.jwt.WCompositeWidget
              eu.webtoolkit.jwt.WTreeTable

public class WTreeTable
extends WCompositeWidget

A table with a navigatable tree in the first column

A WTreeTable implements a tree table, where additional data associated is associated with tree items, which are organized in columns.

Unlike the MVC-based WTreeView widget, the tree renders a widget hierarchy, rather than a hierarhical standard model. This provides extra flexibility (as any widget can be used as contents), at the cost of server-side, client-side and bandwidth resources (especially for large tree tables).

The actual data is organized and provided by WTreeTableNode widgets.

To use the tree table, you must first use addColumn(CharSequence header, WLength width) to specify the additional data columns. Then, you must set the tree root using setTreeRoot(WTreeTableNode root, CharSequence h) and bind additional information (text or other widgets) in each node using WTreeTableNode.setColumnWidget(int column, WWidget widget).

To apply a style to the table header hou should use CSS in conjunction with the style class ("header") that is set for the header row. Alternatively, you may access the header directly using getHeaderWidget(). To apply a different style to each column header, you can access each column header widget using header(int), e.g. to set a style class.

The table cannot be given a height using CSS style rules, instead you must use layout managers, or use WCompositeWidget.resize(WLength width, WLength height).

See Also:
WTreeTableNode, WTreeView

Constructor Detail

WTreeTable

public WTreeTable(WContainerWidget parent)
Construct a new WTreeTable.

The getTreeRoot() is 0. The table should first be properly dimensioned using addColumn(CharSequence header, WLength width) calls, and then data using setTreeRoot(WTreeTableNode root, CharSequence h).

WTreeTable

public WTreeTable()
Construct a new WTreeTable.

Calls this((WContainerWidget)null)

Method Detail

addColumn

public void addColumn(java.lang.CharSequence header,
                      WLength width)
Add an extra column.

Add an extra column, specifying the column header and a column width. The extra columns are numbered from 1 as column 0 contains the tree itself. The header for column 0 (the tree itself) is specified in setTreeRoot(WTreeTableNode root, CharSequence h), and the width of column 0 takes the remaining available width.

getColumnCount

public int getColumnCount()
The number of columns in this table.

Returns the number of columns in the table, including in the count column 0 (which contains the tree).

See Also:
addColumn(CharSequence header, WLength width)

setTreeRoot

public void setTreeRoot(WTreeTableNode root,
                        java.lang.CharSequence h)
Set the tree root.

Sets the data for the tree table, and specify the header for the first column.

See Also:
getTreeRoot(), setTree(WTree root, CharSequence h)

See Also:

columnWidth

public WLength columnWidth(int column)
Returns the column width for the given column.

The width of the first column (with index 0), containing the tree, is implied by the width set for the table minus the width of all other columns.

See Also:
addColumn(CharSequence header, WLength width), setTreeRoot(WTreeTableNode root, CharSequence h)

header

public WText header(int column)
Returns the header for the given column.

See Also:
addColumn(CharSequence header, WLength width), setTreeRoot(WTreeTableNode root, CharSequence h)

getHeaderWidget

public WWidget getHeaderWidget()
Returns the header widget.

This is the widget that contains the column headers.
